block.p: Sunni Leaders Look To Post-Election Politics Sunni Arab leaders who have been the most vocal in calling for a boycott or postponement of the coming elections say they intend to get involved in politics after the vote, including taking part in writing a permanent constitution.

Documents from the Army's criminal investigation division describe complaints of abuse of Iraqi civilians, including some citing the use of electric shocks and forced sodomy, that may not have been investigated fully by the military.

Scotland Yard's aggressive investigation of Sheik Omar Bakri Muhammad, the leader of Britain's largest Muslim group, is part of an increasing effort to monitor and restrict militant imams in Britain and Europe.
Security forces in Iraq have captured two senior aides to the Jordanian militant, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, bringing in his top bomb-maker and his propaganda chief, an Iraqi government spokesman said.

Pentagon Units Questioned Members of Congress said they would seek to determine whether the Pentagon had overstepped its bounds by creating secret battlefield intelligence units within the Defense Intelligence Agency.

New Leader Meets With Putin President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine and President Vladimir V. Putin, at a meeting at the Kremlin, moved publicly to set aside what had seemed to be sharp political and personal differences.

East Jerusalem Land Dispute The Israeli government approved a measure last summer that says it can seize land in East Jerusalem owned by Palestinians who live elsewhere, the government and a lawyer for the Palestinians said.

Gov. Bush's Role Ended In Feeding Tube Dispute The United States Supreme Court essentially ended legal efforts by Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida to keep a brain-damaged woman alive with a feeding tube against her husband's wishes when it declined to hear a challenge brought by the governor's office.

Sterile Couples Look Overseas Though the majority of Americans who are infertile look for help close to home, a small number are seeking help in places like South Africa, Germany and Canada, where the costs can be much lower.

Social Security Debate Grows The Bush administration, facing opposition over its plan to overhaul Social Security, is looking at new ideas for cutting future benefits that would hit wealthy retirees harder than earners of lower wages.
Senate Democrats threatened new hurdles for President Bush's Cabinet choices and expressed deep misgivings about the Social Security changes at the heart of this year's Republican agenda.

Missile Defense Cost Criticized Shoulder-fired missiles are a threat to civilian jetliners, but putting anti-missile defenses on planes is far too expensive, according to a 62-page study by the RAND Corporation.
More Funds for Vaccine Agenda The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is doubling, to $1.5 billion, its contribution to increase access to basic childhood vaccinations in the world's poorest nations.
Going-Away Party for Ashcroft Several hundred Justice Department employees gathered in the department's Great Hall to bid farewell to the attorney general.
Bush Courts Anti-Abortionists President Bush told demonstrators at an anti-abortion rally in Washingtion that he applauded their cause but saw a long road still ahead.

Senator Clinton Refines Her Stance on Abortion Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, in a speech to abortion rights supporters, firmly restated her support for Roe v. Wade. But she quickly shifted gears, praising the influence of ''religious and moral values'' in delaying the onset of sexual activity in teenagers.

Inquiries Into Fatal Fires Sweeping inquiries into the circumstances behind two fires that killed three New York City firefighters, to be led by the Fire Department and the city's Department of Investigation, are under way.

Fire Cripples 2 Subway Lines A fire in a Lower Manhattan transit control room crippled two of the city's subway lines -- the A and the C -- which may not return to normal capacity for three to five years, officials said.
Antarctic Ice Shelves Thinning Glaciers in Antarctica are thinning and giant ice shelves are disintegrating -- possible indications of global warming, scientists say.
Miriam Rothschild The heiress who was acknowledged as one of the world's most distinguished naturalists, was 96.

Conflict Brewing Over Dollar President Bush's allies in Europe and Asia suspect that his next foreign policy challenge could involve a potential currency crisis, in which a steep plunge in the value of the dollar touches off economic waves around the world.

Convictions in Stock Case Anthony Elgindy, a well-known figure in the Internet world of penny stocks, was convicted on charges that he used confidential information about criminal investigations from an F.B.I. agent to profit illegally in the market.

A Clinic and Corporate Ties The Cleveland Clinic, one of the most entrepreneurial and prestigious medical institutions in the country, is struggling to revamp rules intended to ensure that its doctors' corporate connections do not lead to bias in patient care or academic research.
Editorials: Listen to what the man says; the F.D.A. and Plan B; Mourning for the city's Bravest; Carson, night by night.
